articles.title: Physicists want the next Large Hadron Collider to be climate-friendly
articles.description: Particle colliders use a huge amount of energy, so physicists are evaluating proposed successors to the Large Hadron Collider to optimise efficiency and reduce their climate impact
articles.content:
By Alex Wilkins
An artist’s impression of the proposed Future Circular Collider at CERN
Polar Media/CERN
Physicists planning to build the successor to the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) have started … [+362 chars]

articles.title: UK toilets and showers will need water efficiency labels by 2025
articles.description: Hopes for water and energy bill savings from new efficiency labels for toilets, taps, showers, dishwashers, washing machines and washer-dryers
articles.content:
By Adam Vaughan
New taps in the UK will need to carry a water-efficiency label within three years
zefart/Shutterstock

articles.title: There are thousands more UK deaths than usual and we don’t know why
articles.description: Since April, there have been 22,500 more deaths than expected in the UK. Health experts are concerned but unsure of the causes – which could include covid-19, population ageing and NHS problems
articles.content:
By Jason Arunn Murugesu
Average waiting times for ambulances peaked at 9 minutes 35 seconds in July
ANDY RAIN/EPA-EFE/Shutterstock
The UK has seen an unexplained surge in deaths in recent months, … [+397 chars]

articles.title: Insulin-blocking protein may be the secret to queen ants’ long lives
articles.description: Indian jumping ant queens live nine times longer than worker females in the same colony, which may be due to insulin-blocking proteins they produce once they begin reproduction
articles.content:
By Corryn Wetzel
A worker ant of the Indian jumping ant species
Hua Yan/NYU
A protein that suppresses the production of insulin could be behind the unusually long lives of queens in a species of I… [+2516 chars]

articles.title: Meta AI can tell which words you hear by reading your brainwaves
articles.description: The company behind Facebook has created an AI that could one day be used to help nonverbal people better communicate
articles.content:
By Matthew Sparkes
Are you thinking what I’m hearing?
Gerd Altmann/Pixabay

articles.title: Battery made of crab shell and zinc is rechargeable and biodegradable
articles.description: A zinc battery made using a compound from crab shells can be recharged at least 1000 times and can biodegrade or be recycled at the end of its life
articles.content:
By Christa Lesté-Lasserre
Piles of crab shells could be used to make zinc batteries work more efficiently
Colin Marshall/Alamy Stock Photo

articles.title: Quantum magnet is billions of times colder than interstellar space
articles.description: A magnet made out of ytterbium atoms is only a billionth of a degree warmer than absolute zero. Understanding how it works could help physicists build high temperature superconductors
articles.content:
By Karmela Padavic-Callaghan
Ytterbium atoms have been used to make a very cold magnet
Carlos Clarivan/Science Photo Library

articles.title: Bioengineered plants help produce moth pheromones for pest control
articles.description: Pheromones are often used by farmers for controlling pest insects but the chemical process for producing them is expensive. A method for making them using a bioengineered oil plants could be cheaper
articles.content:
By James Dinneen
The camelina oilseed plant can be used to make insect pheromones
Kurt Miller
A bioengineered oilseed plant can produce a moth sex pheromone molecule used to control insect pests.… [+2399 chars]

articles.title: US authorises the use of dual-variant covid-19 vaccine boosters
articles.description: The US Food and Drug Administration authorised the use of versions of Moderna and Pfizer/BioNTech covid-19 vaccines that target both the original virus and two omicron subvariants

articles.title: AI that can see pain in a mouse's face could aid drug development
articles.description: A new artificial intelligence that monitors mice grimaces to score their pain from 0 to 8 may help researchers judge the effectiveness of a new pain-relieving treatment
articles.content:
By Jason Arunn Murugesu
An artificial intelligence could gauge how much pain a laboratory mouse is in based on its grimaces, potentially aiding the development of pain-relieving drugs
